item.title: Questions over mysterious death in mental health hospital
item.description: An inquest into Maria Morris's death found it was accidental, but her family still have questions over what happened the night she died.

item.title: Targeted prostate cancer screening could save countless lives, says Sunak
item.description: The former PM is among those in favour of targeted screening for men most at risk, but some medical experts are sceptical.

item.title: 'My leg helped rebuild my tongue after cancer'
item.description: A woman from Cornwall says people should be aware after a dental check-up led to her diagnosis.

item.title: Grave concerns over patient safety system in mental health units
item.description: It uses infrared sensors and cameras to monitor patients alone in their rooms, sending alerts to staff when it detects signs of distress.

item.title: Eat kiwi fruit to relieve constipation, says guidance
item.description: New guidance for doctors says focusing on fruit in our diets can help with a really common complaint.

item.title: Watchdog vows Botox crackdown after BBC exposÃ©
item.description: BBC researchers caught pharmacists trying to sell Botox without assessing patients first.

item.title: 'We are inventing captivity medicine': Hospital prepares for freed Israeli hostages
item.description: Several of the hostages will be brought from Gaza to the Rabin Medical Center in Petah Tikva.

item.title: Could I have saved my parents if I'd been taught CPR?
item.description: Cameron McGerr lost both his parents and is campaigning to have life-saving first aid taught in schools.

item.title: Alarming number of people now vape, says WHO
item.description: More than 100 million people, including at least 15 million children, use e-cigarettes, fuelling a new wave of nicotine addiction, say experts.

item.title: First-year resident doctors back strike action over jobs shortage
item.description: British Medical Association say 30,000 medics were chasing 10,000 jobs this year.

item.title: Former England captain Moody reveals MND diagnosis
item.description: Former England captain Lewis Moody says in an exclusive BBC interview he has "a reluctance to look the future in the face".

item.title: Top NHS boss backed surgeon whose failures contributed to deaths
item.description: Seven people died following multiple failures by Karen Booth who continues to work for the NHS.

item.title: 'Why won't anyone give my son access to healthcare?'
item.description: When Harry turned 18, he no longer had access to various healthcare services, his mum says.

item.title: Is it a cold, flu or Covid â and how to avoid the worst
item.description: BBC Morning Live's Dr Oscar Duke shares his advice on how to identify whether you have cold, flu or Covid and how to look after yourself.

item.title: I went undercover as a cleaner at a failing care home. Here's what I witnessed
item.description: Catriona MacPhee worked in a Highland care home for seven weeks as part of BBC Disclosure investigation.

item.title: Covid cases rising with new variants Nimbus and Stratus
item.description: Unwell with a bad throat and temperature? You may have one of the new Covid strains circulating this autumn.

item.title: British veterans with hearing loss start legal battle over 'faulty' earplugs
item.description: Lawyers say the earplugs were used in operations, including in Afghanistan, from 2003 onwards.

item.title: 'Buy one, get one free' deals for unhealthy food banned
item.description: Crisps, sweets, chocolate and fizzy drinks will be covered by restrictions starting in England.

item.title: Surgeon offered womb removals in 'minutes' without proper examination, women say
item.description: Only "good fortune" prevented ex-gynaecologist Daniel Hay from causing more harm to women, a report says.

item.title: Scientists make embryos from human skin DNA for first time
item.description: US scientists testing the technique say it could help people overcome infertility and potentially allow same-sex couples to have a genetically related child.

item.title: Streeting rules out VAT on private healthcare
item.description: The health secretary says "it's not happening", as ministers face questions about the prospect of tax rises.

item.title: Nurses and pharmacists endangering patients by supplying illegal Botox
item.description: An undercover BBC team catch a fake doctor, a pharmacist and a nurse supplying Botox illegally without checks.

item.title: New inquests open into jailed surgeon's patients
item.description: The coroner opens the inquests into the deaths of Pauline Brown and Jennifer Fox.

item.title: Collagen: Do you drink it? Inject it? Rub it on your skin? And does it work?
item.description: Pills, powders and creams promise to top up natural supplies which decrease as we get older.

item.title: Doctors' union warning over online booking safety risk
item.description: GPs are concerned they will be at the end of an "online triage tsunami" when the new system launches.

item.title: 'My baby's brain tumour symptoms were dismissed as colic'
item.description: A mum whose 12-week-old baby underwent emergency surgery for a brain tumour calls for better awareness.

item.title: Can England's rugby heroes inspire more girls to stay in sport?
item.description: Sports groups hope England Women's Rugby World Cup success can boost girls playing sport.

item.title: Prostate cancer symptoms and treatment: What to check for
item.description: One in eight men will be diagnosed with prostate cancer in their lifetime.

item.title: A facelift at 28? Why young people are turning to plastic surgery
item.description: Gone are the days when facelifts were for the ageing wealthy. Now younger people are going under the knife.

item.title: Your nose gets colder when you're stressed. These thermal images show the change
item.description: Psychologists subjected a BBC reporter to a carefully designed thermal camera stress test.

item.title: My eating disorder made me good at lying, says Victoria Beckham
item.description: The former Spice Girl's new Netflix documentary has landed - under the shadow of a reported family feud.

item.title: My late husband's organs transformed the lives of four people
item.description: Mark Hutchinson was only 52 when he died unexpectedly last year after suffering two strokes "out of the blue".

item.title: 'I missed a Â£100 council tax bill while in hospital â the debt ballooned to Â£6k'
item.description: The government says it is taking action to protect people from âaggressive collection practicesâ.

item.title: EastEnders' Kellie Bright on the challenges of being parent of an autistic child
item.description: The soap actor meets families fighting for their childrenâs education for BBC Panorama.

item.title: What exactly is freshers' flu - and why do so many get it?
item.description: It's not an actual flu, and it's rarely serious, but when thousands of students arrive on campus they bring a cocktail of viruses.

item.title: Scientists win Nobel Prize for discovering why immune system does not destroy the body
item.description: The prize-winning discovery explains how the immune system attacks hostile infections, but not the body's own cells.

item.title: How weight-loss injections are turning obesity into a wealth issue
item.description: With claims of a 'two-tier system', could it be that these drugs are exacerbating health inequalities?

item.title: Why I'm challenging Nike, Adidas and Puma over single shoes
item.description: Former Para-athletic world champion Stef Reid says footwear companies are failing amputees.

item.title: What we know about rising autism rates and Trump's unproven Tylenol link
item.description: Some studies have suggested an association between the two, but experts say there is no causal relationship.

item.title: The songs I've chosen to help me prepare for dying
item.description: Music can evoke powerful memories and offers a sense of normality for people dealing with illness or death.

item.title: 'My girl can't walk or talk': Searching for answers in Wales' rare disease cluster
item.description: Families affected by a rare inherited disease say they have had to "scramble" for information.

item.title: How to avoid period leaks - the pros and cons of cups, pants and tampons
item.description: Here is a guide to how each product works and the pros and cons to help you decide what might suit you.

item.title: Cut and bulk: Teenagers explain why they want to get ripped
item.description: The quest for brick-like abs has become serious business - even if you're only in Year 8.

item.title: Why the world is watching RFK's fight with US health agency
item.description: The US health secretary's plans could have a huge impact on health policy not just in the US, but across the globe.

item.title: The trade in US body parts that's completely legal - but ripe for exploitation
item.description: Human remains can mean profits. But there is an emotional debate about the ethics of the industry.

item.title: Sitting up straight isn't the only secret to good posture - here are three more tips
item.description: Here are Dr Xand's three suggestions on how to look after your back without turning into a statue.

item.title: Will Serena Williams's weight-loss admission help shed stigma of anti-obesity drugs?
item.description: Could her comments instil a new sense of confidence in those using the drugs and quieten the critics?

item.title: What is chickenpox and how can I get my child vaccinated?
item.description: The NHS in England and Wales will start offering the MMRV vaccine to young children from January 2026.

item.title: The teenage caffeine pouch trend troubling US experts
item.description: Some social media influencers are pushing products to young gym-goers and students, health experts warn.

item.title: Sleep, exercise, hydrate - do we really need to stick to recommended daily doses?
item.description: As a study casts doubt on the daily steps maxim, we take a look at some other health benchmarks weâre often told to strive for.

item.title: Is the most expensive lip balm always the best?
item.description: Do you need to spend more to get the best for your chapped lips?

item.title: Ketamine helped me escape my negative thoughts - then it nearly killed me
item.description: Young people are taking dangerous amounts of ket because it's cheap, easily available and helps them "disconnect", experts say.

item.title: The English neighbourhood that claims to hold the secret to fixing the NHS
item.description: With public satisfaction in the NHS just 21%, one area has a plan to shake up its services that could reduce GP waiting lists, as well as unblock hospital beds - but can it really work nationwide?

item.title: How does the disposable vape ban work, and how harmful is vaping?
item.description: The disposable vape ban is designed to reduce environmental damage and protect children's health.

item.title: Labour's plan for benefits throws up a bigger dilemma
item.description: The debate has sparked a wider dilemma about the broader purpose of welfare

item.title: First place in British Isles set to approve right to die
item.description: Laws in the Isle of Man to let terminally ill adults end their own lives are in the last stages of debate.

item.title: Generation K: The disturbing rise of ketamine abuse among young people
item.description: Increasing numbers of young people are using the drug, experts say. The health impacts can be catastrophic.

item.title: Assisted dying bill: What is in proposed law?
item.description: The proposed law would allow some terminally ill adults to end their own lives. But there are requirements.

item.title: 'My first cervical screening was over before I knew it'
item.description: The BBC speaks to six people about their first cervical screening, and what they wish they'd known beforehand.

item.title: Is the system letting down people who were harmed by Covid vaccines?
item.description: People affected by rare blood clots say they feel they have been airbrushed out of the pandemic.

item.title: How will weight-loss drugs change our relationship with food?
item.description: The rise of these treatments has major implications for how we think about obesity, says James Gallagher.

item.title: NHS needs better plan around weight loss jabs, warn experts
item.description: Experts call for an urgent review of obesity treatment services amid booming demand for weight loss jabs.

item.title: How many of us will end up being diagnosed with ADHD?
item.description: Experts suggest that the number of people with ADHD is actually going to remain steady.

item.title: The junior doctors' strikes may be over. But is trouble ahead?
item.description: The end of the pay dispute sounded too good to be true. And now some are wondering if it might be.

item.title: Union and government to restart talks on ending doctor dispute
item.description: BMA says there is window of opportunity in coming weeks to reach a settlement after 12 strikes.

item.title: Doctors' union agrees to resume talks with Streeting
item.description: But the health secretary says he will not negotiate on pay, adding that the union has lost goodwill with their five-day walkout.

item.title: The doctor strike has ended - what comes next?
item.description: With doctors returning to work after five-day walkout, is there an opportunity for talks to re-start?

item.title: Why did resident doctors strike and what are they paid?
item.description: Resident doctors in England went on strike over pay for five days at the end of July 2025.

item.title: Covid care home policy was 'least worst decision' - Hancock
item.description: Former health secretary Matt Hancock denied claims the government's attempt to throw a protective ring around care homes in early 2020 was empty rhetoric.

item.title: Covid inquiry hears of 'generational slaughter'
item.description: Relatives of care home residents tell the Covid inquiry they will never get over how their loved ones died.

item.title: Covid inquiry to look at impact on care services
item.description: The Covid inquiry will examine the impact of the pandemic on care services, starting on Monday.

item.title: The Covid Inquiry Podcast: 'I wasn't the decision maker'
item.description: The Inquiry hears from the lead of the test and trace unit

item.title: Cash to isolate 'would have cut Covid deaths'
item.description: Baroness Dido Harding tells Covid inquiry Rishi Sunak blocked higher support payments.

item.title: Johnson wanted tighter Covid rules, inquiry hears
item.description: In his diaries, Lord Vallance wrote that ex-PM thought rules were not ruthless enough.

item.title: Hancock criticises 'wholly naive' Covid inquiry
item.description: The former health secretary was giving evidence about medical equipment deals during the pandemic.

item.title: Mone accuses Covid inquiry of 'cover-up'
item.description: She says husband Doug Barrowman and her are targets of a "politically motivated witch hunt".

item.title: Michael Gove denies trying to circumvent Dyson ventilator checks
item.description: Former cabinet minister says it would be ludicrous to suggest he tried to shortcut safety checks in the pandemic.

item.title: Michelle Mone-linked PPE firm evidence to be heard in private
item.description: Covid inquiry says hearings into the firm, led by Michelle Mone's husband, must be held in closed session.

item.title: Large UK-wide pandemic preparedness tests planned this year
item.description: The stress test will involve thousands of people to help the UK prepare for potential future threats.

item.title: Families failed by Covid jabs tell inquiry of pain
item.description: They said there was no support after the death and harm suffered by their loved ones.

item.title: NHS hours from PPE running out in Covid - Hancock
item.description: Former health secretary tells inquiry some healthcare settings did run out - "and it was awful".

item.title: Covid inquiry told Treasury blocked NHS bed request
item.description: NHS England chief executive Amanda Pritchard says the decision, in July 2020, was very disappointing.

item.title: Covid inquiry told top NHS doctor was terrified
item.description: Sir Stephen Powis says points-based tool was drawn up should need to prioritise patients have arisen.

item.title: How close were hospitals to collapse in Covid?
item.description: The Covid inquiry restarts its live hearings this week, after senior staff in the NHS revealed just how close some hospitals were to collapse

item.title: Covid inquiry told of trust do-not-resuscitate rule
item.description: Patients' families were âhorrified but not surprisedâ when told the blanket policy had been in place.

item.title: We were not treated as parents, Covid inquiry told
item.description: Mum of premature twins says rigid restrictions on birthing wards during Covid were traumatic.

item.title: Report shows 'stark' gender gap in HIV prevention
item.description: A meeting will discuss how to tackle what organisers say is a growing inequality in HIV prevention.

item.title: 'Marginalised and menopausal' women given spotlight
item.description: Women from ethnic minority communities typically experience perimenopause symptoms earlier and for longer.

item.title: Pharmacies can issue UTI drugs without GP visit
item.description: From October, most pharmacies in Wales can treat women under 64 who have urinary tract infections.

item.title: First local endometriosis support centre to open
item.description: The charity-run centre in Hull will help women with the condition that can cause extreme pain.

item.title: 'Severe period pain â it's not normal'
item.description: Reah Steer was prescribed the contraceptive pill, which only disguised her endometriosis.

item.title: 'Prescription for time at the coast helped me'
item.description: A woman from Plymouth describes her health improving after a "green social prescription".

item.title: School Council Network focusing on digital safety
item.description: The meetings allow primary and secondary school councils to shape policy directly with government.

item.title: How to have a social life - even when it feels hard
item.description: Advice on staying connected with friends when life feels like a never-ending to-do list.

item.title: One way Michael Rosen has coped with the death of his son
item.description: "You donât die as a human being, you live on with others," Rosen told Saturday Live.

item.title: Gym with wellbeing focus welcomes lottery boost
item.description: The Soma Space offers combined strength training and psychotherapy, and prospective clients can be referred.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: Cystic fibrosis care, AI in cancer screening & science of run clubs.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: Shingles vaccine to reduce dementia risk? Antibiotic resistant gonorrhoea & tech trousers

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: We investigate the safety of melatonin as a sleep aid, and should you eat your placenta?

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: We try to figure out why drug deaths are at an all-time high - and what can be done.

item.title: The Climate Question
item.description: Most of the world will be living in cities by 2050. How can we improve their design?

item.title: 'It saved me' - how Everton in the Community is changing lives
item.description: Everton defender James Tarkowski speaks with lifelong fan Sam to discuss how the club are supporting members of the community with mental health challenges.

item.title: How singer Calum Scott stays grounded
item.description: Singer-songwriter Calum Scott speaks about resilience and staying grounded for World Mental Health Day.

item.title: Miranda Hart on the healing power of nature walks
item.description: Miranda Hart is interviewed about her recovery from fatigue on Woman's Hour
